title: Irwell Sculpture Trail Walking Route

images.title: Wesley Trevor Johnston / On the Irwell Sculpture Trail, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Delightful riverside sculpture near Summerseat

images.title: Paul Anderson / Irwell Sculpture Trail Stubbins, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: These old stone sets run for about a half mile section between Ramsbottom and Stubbins and are part of The Irwell Sculpture Trail that follows a well established 30 mile footpath stretching from Salford Quays through Bury into Rossendale and up to the Pennines above Bacup. The field to the left is a flood plain which is used when the River Irwell bursts its banks like it did in January 2007

images.title: Edward Smith / Eye-Glass Sculpture on the Irwell Valley Trail, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Eye-glass sculpture on Irwell Sculpture Trail in Bury, Lancashire

images.title: liz dawson / Sculpture - Irwell Sculpture Trail near Lumb, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Sculpture near Lumb

images.title: Dennis Turner / Sculpture, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Stone Cycle sculpture by Julie Edwards at Burrs Country Park.

images.title: Paul Rudge / In the Picture, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: "Frame" sculpture 'In the Picture' near Strongstry. Nice view of the countryside through this eye catching piece

images.title: David Dixon [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: James and the ball of fire. A striking piece near Radcliffe

images.title: Paul Anderson [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Burrs Mill Chimney, Bury

description: Follow the River Irwell on this splendid waterside walk through Greater Manchester and enjoy over 70 artworks by renowned artists. The walk starts at Salford Quays and follows the trail north through Radcliffe, Bury and Ramsbottom towards Bacup. The walk visits some lovely riverside country parks including Clifton Country Park and Burrs Country Park. You also pass Outwood Country Park where you can pick up the Outwood Trail. Another route highlight is a nice stretch along the Bury Canal where you'll pass the pretty Elton Reservoir. Near Rawtenstall and Ramsbottom you will pass close to the Peel Tower. The monument is dedicated to Sir Robert Peel, the 19th century Prime Minister considered the father of modern British policing. It's a major local landmark and worth the climb to the top for the views over the area. The trail also visits a series of art galleries and museums including the Lowry and the East Lancashire Railway.
